sentence: The Procter & Gamble CompanyPG recently announced that it has signed a definitive agreement to sell 43 beauty brands to Coty Inc. COTY in a complex $12.5 billion transaction.

The deal will include P&G's global salon professional hair care and color brands like Wella; color cosmetics brands like Covergirl and Max Factor; fine fragrance businesses like Hugo Boss, Gucci and Dolce & Gabbana; and some other hair styling brands.
The company is, however, retaining the hair, skin and personal care brands such as Pantene, Olay and SK-II.
Following the deal closure, P&G shareholders will own 52% of the much bigger Coty, while Coty shareowners will have the remaining 48%.
The divesture of the brands are expected to result in approximately 2 cents to 3 cents per share dilution prior to the closing of the transaction, expected in the second half of calendar 2016.
However, after the transaction is closed, P&G claims it will pay dividends and repurchase shares worth up to $70 billion over the next four years (2016-2019).
The lower share count coupled with elimination of overhead costs associated with the beauty brands are expected to offset the impact of the lost profit from sales of these products.
P&G plans to execute the transaction either as a split-off or spin-off transaction.

Though a final decision is pending, the company prefers to carry out a Reverse Morris Trust split-off transaction in which the Beauty business will be separated followed by a merger with a subsidiary of Coty.
In this transaction, P&G shareholders can exchange their shares for those of Coty.
The divesture is in line with P&G's portfolio strengthening and simplification plans announced in August last year.
Under the plan, the company aims to streamline its business to focus more on its biggest brands, including the Billion Dollar Brands like Tide, Pampers and Oral-B.
Also, the company will eliminate (partner, divest or discontinue) 60% of the brands (equating to roughly 100) whose sales and profits have been declining over the past three years.

Once the divestures are completed, P&G will have a portfolio of about 65 consumer and shopper preferred leading brands (focusing on 10 categories) that have accounted for 85% of the company's sales and over 95% of its profits.
In keeping with the plan, last year, P&G sold off its American and Asian pet care business to Mars, Inc. in July and the European pet care business to Spectrum Brands, Inc. SPB in December.
Moreover, the company has signed a deal to divest the Duracell batteries business to Berkshire Hathaway, Inc. BRK.B in exchange for Berkshire's equity stake in P&G.
In addition, the company has already exited the Bleach business, Vicks VapoStream, Camay and Zest bar soap brands, and several skin care and fragrance brands.
The divesture of the underperforming business will help P&G to concentrate on its core businesses which have greater growth potential.
Moreover, we believe that a smaller and more focused company should be able to grow faster, create more value and be much easier to manage.
As regards Coty, which manufactures Calvin Klein perfume, the purchase of P&G's famous brands will make it one of the largest global beauty companies with combined sales of more than $10 billion.
It will expand the company's exposure in the growing international markets like Brazil and Japan, thereby providing a strong platform for future growth.
